DOC.HEAD: Romanian Unrest May be Beginning of End for Ceausescu, Analysts Say
Eds: SUBS 8th graf, bgng: The current xxx to CORRECT that Brasov is not near Timisoara or Arad.
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The unrest in Romania may be the beginning of the end for strongman Nicolae Ceausescu, who was hailed 24 years ago as a Soviet bloc maverick but is increasingly denounced for his repressive policies. ``We are definitely in the twilight of the Ceausescu era,'' said F. Stephen Larabee, vice president of the Institute for East-West Security Studies in New York. The Soviet foreign minister and the White House both condemned Ceausescu's use of violence to crush demonstrations in the Romanian city of Timisoara, where according to some reports as many as 400 people died. But Ceausescu, who has ruled Romania with an iron hand since 1965, ``is going to be a harder nut to crack'' than communist leaders swept from power in the Soviet bloc nations of Poland, East Germany, Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Bulgaria, said James Brown, a specialist in East European affairs at the RAND Corp. in Los Angeles. Romania has been a maverick in the Soviet camp for decades _ boycotting Warsaw Pact exercises, trading with the West against Kremlin wishes and most recently balking at the democratic reforms of Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Although Ceausescu may be able to survive in the short term, his days seem numbered, said Larabee, Brown and other analysts. ``This incident or some other might open up an explosion of popular dissent, or some group in the leadership, such as the military, may decide to get rid of him. Sometime or another, something has to give,'' said Raymond Garthoff, a former U.S. ambassador to Bulgaria and now a senior scholar at the Brookings Institution in Washington. The current unrest in Romania began as a reaction to repressions against the Hungarian minority in the nearby cities of Timisoara and Arad, along with the more distant city of Brasov, but reports indicate that ethnic Romanians may have joined the demonstrations. Experts say that is bad news for Ceausescu. Ceausescu was once a favorite of U.S. leaders because he refused to allow Romanian troops to join Warsaw Pact military maneuvers, was the only Soviet bloc leader to maintain full relations with Israel and traded with Western nations against the wishes of Moscow. In 1969, then-President Richard Nixon went to Romania in the first U.S. state visit to a Soviet bloc nation. Ceausesu's widely reported human rights abuses chilled U.S.-Romanian relations, however, and the United States last year withdrew trade favors from Romania, costing that nation as much as $250 million annually. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater harshly criticized Romania on Tuesday. ``The United States condemns the brutal use of police force by the Romanian government against protesters in Timisoara and other cities,'' Fitzwater told reporters. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said that if the reports of bloodshed were true, ``I can only express my very profound regret. We are categorically opposed to the use of force.'' Romania has been a maverick since the late 1950s when Ceausescu's predecessor rejected a Kremlin plan to more closely integrate the Romanian economy into Soviet bloc by selling Moscow and its allies oil and other natural resources. Instead, the Romanians sold their oil to the West and used the money to industrialize. Ceausescu became party leader in 1965 and refused to allow Romanian forces to take part in Warsaw Pact exercises. He was the only Warsaw Pact leader to refuse to take part in the 1968 Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia. He denounced the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan in 1979 and refused to join the Soviet bloc boycott of the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles. Throughout that period, the Romanians took advantage of the Sino-Soviet dispute, playing Moscow off against Beijing. As reforms have swept Eastern Europe, Ceausescu has kept close ties with conservatives in Beijing and counts as his closest allies hardline communist leaders in China, North Korea and Cuba, Brown said.
Bryan Brumley, a former Associated Press correspondent in Warsaw and Moscow, writes on national security affairs from Washington.
